case_name: O.RM.M.SP. SV. Firm v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 751 of 1965 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 751 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated December 18, 1962 of Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 143 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 18, 1962 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 143 of 1960.

facts.text: Appellant is firm called O.RM.M.SP. SV. Firm registered under S. 26A of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant  hereinafter called the assessee  was a firm called O.RM.M.SP. SV. Firm which was registered under S. 26 A  of the Income-tax Act, 1922  hereinafter called the 1922 Act .

facts.text: Prior to constitution of the firm, partners were members of Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to the companystitution of the firm, the partners were members of a Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: Hindu undivided family consisted of Meyyappa Chettiar and his two brothers.

anchor.surface_text: The family which companysisted of Meyyappa Chettiar and his two brothers carried on money-lending business in India

facts.text: Family carried on money-lending business in India and former Federated Malaya States, assessed under 1918 Act.

anchor.surface_text: and in the former Federated Malaya States and it was assessed under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1918  hereinafter called the 1918 Act .

facts.text: Disruption of joint family status on June 2, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: There was a disruption of the joint family status on June 2, 1938, and thereafter the members of the family

facts.text: After disruption, members continued business as partners.

anchor.surface_text: companytinued the business as partners. In the companyrse of the assessment for the year 1939-40 it was claimed

facts.text: In assessment for 1939-40, Meyyappa Chettiar claimed income from April 13, 1938 to June 2, 1938 not liable u/s 25(3) 1918 Act.

anchor.surface_text: by Meyyappa Chettiar, one of the members of the family that having regard to the severance of joint family status, the income of the family from April 13, 1938 to June 2, 1938 was number liable to be taxed

facts.text: Income-tax Officer accepted partition but rejected contention of no tax liability.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer accepted the fact of partition amongst the members of the family, but rejected the companytention that the family was number liable to pay tax on the profits for the said period.

facts.text: High Court held no discontinuance u/s 25(3), but succession by firm.

anchor.surface_text: After receipt of the reference the High Court held that there was numberdiscontinuance of the business within the meaning of s. 25 3 . The view taken by the High Court was that when a Hindu undivided family carrying on a business, which was taxed under the 1918 Act, became disrupted

facts.text: Firm dissolved on March 2, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The firm was dissolved on March 2, 1952.

facts.text: In assessment 1952-53, assessee applied for relief u/s 25(3) 1922 Act, rejected by ITO on March 7, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment for the year 1952-53 the assessee applied for relief under s. 25 3  of the 1922 Act. The claim was rejected by the Income-tax Officer on March 7, 1956.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed appeal, holding foreign business not assessed under 1918 Act but receipts in India.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee preferred an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who dismissed the appeal holding that in the case of business carried on in foreign territory the business as such is number assessed under S. 3 of the 1918 Act

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal allowed appeal in part, entitled to relief except house properties income.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee took the matter in further appeal to the appellate Tribunal which companysidered that the assessee was entitled to relief under S. 25  3  of the 1922 Act except for the income received from the house properties in Malaya.

facts.text: Tribunal referred questions to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Both the assessee and the Department applied to the appellate Tribunal for reference of the questions of law to the High Court. The appellate Tribunal allowed the applications and stated a case to the High Court on the following questions of law

facts.text: High Court held assessee not entitled to relief u/s 25(3) 1922 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the assessee was number entitled to relief under s. 25 3  of the 1922 Act and accordingly answered both the questions in favour of the Department.

facts.text: Assessee taxed on remittances received from profits of foreign business under 1918 Act.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found by the appellate Tribunal that the assessee was taxed on remittances received from and out of the profits of the foreign business.

facts.text: Foreign business at Penang, Ipoh and Kambar.

anchor.surface_text: in respect of foreign business at Penang, Ipoh and Kambar ?

facts.text: Rental income from house properties owned by foreign firm.

anchor.surface_text: with regard to rental income from house properties owned by the foreign firm which was discontinued

facts.text: Supreme Court held assessee entitled to relief for foreign business u/s 25(3).

anchor.surface_text: The first question must therefore be answered in favour of the assessee and it must be held that the assessee is entitled to both parts of relief companytemplated under s. 25 3

facts.text: Supreme Court held assessee entitled to relief for rental income u/s 25(3).

anchor.surface_text: it must accordingly be held that the assessee is entitled to relief under S. 25 3  of the 1922 Act with regard to the rental income from the house properties

facts.text: Appeal allowed, High Court judgment set aside.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons the judgment of the Madras High Court is set aside and this appeal must be allowed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: When the 1922 Act was brought into force on April 1, 1922, two assessments in respect of the same income for the year 1921-22 had to be made... resulting in double taxation... the legislature enacted the exemption prescribed by s. 25 3 .

concepts.interpretation: Purpose of s.25(3) to avoid double taxation from change in assessment year basis

issues.text: The first question to be considered in this appeal is whether the assessee is entitled to both parts of relief contemplated under s. 25 3 of the 1922 Act in respect of the foreign business at Penang, lpoh and Kambar

anchor.surface_text: The first question to be considered in this appeal is whether the assessee is entitled to both parts of relief contemplated under s. 25 3 of the 1922 Act in respect of the foreign business at Penang, lpoh and Kambar. The controversy between the parties turns on the question whether the foreign business

issues.text: The controversy between the parties turns on the question whether the foreign business of the assessee was at any time charged under the provisions of the 1918 Act

anchor.surface_text: The controversy between the parties turns on the question whether the foreign business of the assessee was at any time charged under the provisions of the 1918 Act. It has been found by the appellate Tribunal that the assessee was taxed on remittances received from and out of the profits of the foreign business.

issues.text: The question for determination is whether the foreign business of the assessee was at any time charged under the provisions of s. 3 of the 1918 Act

anchor.surface_text: The question for determination is whether the foreign business of the assessee was at any time charged under the provisions of s. 3 of the 1918 Act. It has been found in this case that the entire income of the foreign business was remitted to the assessee and tax imposed on that income under the 1918 Act.

holdings.text: the foreign business of the assessee must be held to be charged under the provisions of the 1918 Act within the meaning of s. 25 3  of the 1922 Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that in the context of these facts the foreign business of the assessee must be held to be charged under the provisions of the 1918 Act within the meaning of s. 25 3  of the 1922 Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax imposed on entire remitted profits derived from foreign business under s.3 of 1918 Act constitutes charging the business as charge is on receipt in British India in relation to the business.

holdings.text: the assessee is entitled to both parts of relief contemplated under s. 25 3  of the 1922 Act in respect of the foreign business at Penang, lpoh and Kambar.

anchor.surface_text: The first question must therefore be answered in favour of the assessee and it must be held that the assessee is entitled to both parts of relief contemplated under s. 25 3

holdings.reasoning_summary: Foreign business charged under 1918 Act via tax on remittances; business not unit of assessment but tax on owner suffices per Chugandas; Palaniappa impliedly overruled.

holdings.text: the view adopted by the High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. V.R.M. Palaniappa Chettiar and Others must be taken to be impliedly over-ruled by the recent decision of this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City v. Chugandas Co.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the view adopted by the High Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. V.R.M. Palaniappa Chettiar and Others    must be taken to be impliedly over- ruled by the recent decision of this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chugandas holds tax charged on owner of business qualifies for s.25(3); inconsistent with requiring tax on business as such.

holdings.text: business, profession or vocation is not a unit of assessment. When, therefore S. 25 3  enacts that tax was charged at any time on any business, it is intended that the tax was at any time charged on the owner of any business.

anchor.surface_text: It was further observed in that case that tax is charged under the Income-tax Acts on specific units... business, profession or vocation is not a unit of assessment. When, therefore S. 25 3  enacts that tax was charged at any time on any business,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopting Chugandas: tax units are persons/firms; charging owner re business income under 1918 Act satisfies condition for relief.

holdings.text: the assessee is entitled to relief under S. 25 3  of the 1922 Act with regard to the rental income from the house properties owned by the foreign firm which was discontinued in the year of account.

anchor.surface_text: it must accordingly be held that the assessee is entitled to relief under S. 25 3  of the 1922 Act with regard to the rental income from the house properties

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Chugandas ratio: heads of income for computation only; do not delimit business income; rental from properties owned by firm part of business.

holdings.text: the heads of income described in S. 6 of the 1922 Act, and further elaborated for the purposes of computation in ss. 7 to 10 and 12, 12A, 12AA and 12B, are intended merely to indicate the classes of income. The heads do not exhaustively delimit sources from which income arises.

anchor.surface_text: It was explained by this Court that the heads of income described in S. 6 of the 1922 Act, and further elaborated for the purposes of computation in ss. 7 to IO and 12, 12A, 12AA and 12B, are intended merely to indicate the classes of income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Chugandas: classification under heads does not cease income being business income; for computation purposes only.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras S. V.R.M. Palaniappa Chettiar and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras S. V.R.M. Palaniappa Chettiar and Others 1 in which it was held that the words on which in S. 25 4  of the 1922 Act cannot be interpreted as meaning with reference to which and that in order to claim and avail the benefit under S. 25 4  the tax clearly should be charged on the business as such under the 1918 Act.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. S.V.R.M. Palaniappa Chettiar and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: tax on foreign business charged only on remittances received in British India does not constitute tax charged 'on the business' under the 1918 Act for purposes of relief under s. 25(3)/(4) of 1922 Act
precedents.cited_holding: the words 'on which tax was charged' cannot be interpreted as 'with reference to which'; tax must be on the business as such

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. V.R.M. Palaniappa Chettiar and Others

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras v. S. V.R.M. Palaniappa Chettiar and Others    must be taken to be impliedly over- ruled by the recent decision of this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax. Bombay City-1 v. Chugandas Co. 2

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. S.V.R.M. Palaniappa Chettiar and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: view that tax must be charged on the business as such under 1918 Act for s.25(3) relief is incorrect

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax. Bombay City-1 v. Chugandas Co. 2

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax. Bombay City-1 v. Chugandas Co. 2 in which the question was whether the interest on securities formed part of the assessees business income for the purpose of the exemption from tax under s. 25 3  of the 1922 Act.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Chugandas & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: s.25(3) relief available if tax charged under 1918 Act on owner of business; business not a unit of assessment; exemption not restricted to income under 'business' head
precedents.cited_holding: assessee entitled to exemption under s.25(3) in respect of interest on securities; no reason to restrict to profits and gains of business head

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City-, v. Chugandas and Company 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City-, v. Chugandas and Company 1  which has already been referred to. In that case, the assessee firm, a dealer in securities holding securities as its stock-in-trade, had been charged to tax under the 1918 Act, in respect of business.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Chugandas and Company
precedents.cited_proposition: interest on securities can form part of business income for s.25(3) exemption; heads of income are for computation only, do not delimit business income
precedents.cited_holding: the ratio applies to rental income from house properties as part of business
